content.title: HUMAN RIGHTS AND SOCIAL AND ECONOMIC IMPACTS
content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1

content.text: Lesson 1 Overview

While reducing harmful greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, the transition to renewable energy technologies also introduces challenges tied to human rights and social and economic dynamics. Recognizing and proactively addressing these complexities is paramount to ensuring an equitable and just transition. This lesson examines human rights concerns, community-level social impacts, and economic ramifications linked to the shift toward sustainable energy. It also explores strategies to mitigate these issues, safeguarding a transition that prioritizes justice and equity.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: free, prior, and informed consent (fpic)
concepts.body: Free, prior, and informed consent (FPIC) is a principle that ensures that indigenous peoples and local communities have the right to give or withhold their consent for projects affecting their land, resources, and rights, based on full information and without coercion.

concepts.title: inclusive policy frameworks
concepts.body: Inclusive policy frameworks are guidelines and strategies designed to ensure that all individuals, regardless of their background or circumstances, have equal access to opportunities, resources, and decision-making processes in various sectors, including social, economic, and environmental areas.

content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1:Human rights concerns

content.text: Renewable energy projects are often heralded as a solution for climate change and the transition away from fossil fuels. However, they can come with a range of ethical and human rights challenges that need to be navigated to ensure a fair and equitable shift to renewable energy sources. A central ethical dilemma inherent in these endeavours revolves around their dependence on extractive industries.

These industries face significant challenges related to human rights, Indigenous Peoples' rights, and environmental justice. Ensuring responsible resource management requires prioritizing human rights and ethical considerations alongside economic development. Similar concerns have been raised regarding oil, gas, and coal extraction, which frequently cause substantial social and environmental harm. Human rights concerns loom large over renewable energy projects, particularly concerning land acquisition, community displacement, and labor rights violations. The extraction of critical minerals often disrupts ecosystems, resulting in habitat destruction and potential health hazards for local populations. Upholding and protecting the fundamental rights of individuals impacted by these activities is pivotal for ethical renewable energy development.

As we progress with the transition to clean energy, it is crucial to pause and reflect on whether we have adequately assessed the human rights and social implications accompanying this transition. The unsettling issue of land dispossession affecting indigenous communities in regions designated for renewable energy and critical mineral mining projects can have severe repercussions, jeopardizing livelihoods and disrupting access to vital resources like food (Scheidel et al., 2023). Take, for instance, the production of lithium-ion batteries, which power our electronic devices and vehicles, presents its own set of challenges. Minerals such as lithium, cobalt, and nickel, crucial for these batteries, are often sourced through practices that disregard human rights and environmental well-being. In regions like the Democratic Republic of Congo (DRC), communities face forced evictions, child labour, and dangerous working conditions in mines. Indigenous communities in areas like the Salar de Atacama also face threats to their rights and ecosystems due to lithium extraction.

On the other hand, we have examples such as Albemarle, a specialty chemicals company, which has voluntarily shared 3.5% of its Chilean operations revenues with the Atacama Indigenous Council since 2017. Albemarle has a series of conditions that are related to the use of new technologies in the production process and carrying out consultation processes with Indigenous communities along with other prior requirements.

The rush to find new sources of battery minerals has led to increased interest in deep-sea mining, a practice that involves extracting minerals from the ocean floor, often in fragile ecosystems that are not yet fully understood. This poses severe risks to marine biodiversity, the climate, and the livelihoods of coastal communities. Companies involved in sourcing these minerals must respect human rights and provide remedies for any abuses linked to their operations or business relations. A just transition is imperative—one where human rights considerations are intricately woven into all climate actions.

Mary Robinson, former UN High Commissioner for Human Rights, emphasizes the importance of recognizing that actions beneficial for the planet may not always align with the well-being of people. Hence, a just transition is imperative, one where human rights considerations are intricately woven into all climate actions. This highlights the need for energy policies to be crafted with a nuanced understanding of trade-offs, co-benefits, and competing priorities, balancing energy security and climate objectives with the human rights of stakeholders, including local communities and workers.

At the project implementation level, renewable energy initiatives must be meticulously planned, financed, constructed, and integrated into energy systems with a keen eye on human rights, especially in areas where vulnerable communities reside. There are positive developments in this direction. Many renewable project developers demonstrate effective community engagement and consultation, championing community investment programs and advocating for community ownership of projects. Furthermore, major players in the global energy arena are beginning to prioritize human rights, evident in their establishment of human rights policies and the integration of social and environmental considerations into energy investment decisions. Additionally, the engineering and construction sectors are actively addressing human rights challenges through collaborative efforts, as documented in a recent study by the Business and Human Rights Resource Centre. Indigenous communities, often residing in areas rich in renewable energy resources, face heightened risks of rights violations. Extractive practices can encroach upon indigenous lands, jeopardizing cultural heritage, livelihoods, and land connections. Respecting and upholding indigenous rights are not only an ethical imperative but also pivotal for fostering sustainable and inclusive renewable energy initiatives.

Collaboration at the global level is essential to establish and enforce international standards guiding responsible resource management in renewable energy production. Ultimately, transitioning to sustainable alternatives is indispensable for reducing reliance on extractive industries and fostering ecological and social sustainability in renewable energy projects. Embracing renewable energy sources, promoting circular economies, and exploring innovative technologies are key components of this transition. By addressing ethical dilemmas and sustainability challenges, renewable energy projects can contribute to a more equitable and sustainable future for all. The shift to renewable energy must avoid harming people or damaging the environment. Governments and businesses have a chance to create a fair transition that learns from the mistakes of the fossil fuel era. By respecting human rights and protecting nature, they can ensure renewable energy systems are sustainable and benefit everyone.

content.title: A. The Escazú Agreement

content.text: The Regional Agreement on Access to Information, Public Participation and Justice in Environmental Matters in Latin America and the Caribbean, better known as the Escazú Agreement (Spanish: Acuerdo de Escazú), was adopted on March 4, 2018 in Escazú, Costa Rica and entered into force on 22 April 2021 (Source: Human Rights Watch, 2023). It is the world’s first international, legally binding treaty to enhance environmental protection. It guarantees people’s right to obtain environmental information and to participate in decision-making that affects their lives and environment. It also requires governments to provide safe and enabling conditions for environmental defenders and ensure that those responsible for violence and intimidation against them are investigated and prosecuted. The treaty is supported by the Economic Commission for Latin America and the Caribbean (ECLAC) - who recently launched a website to support its implementation and compliance: Escazú Agreement CSIC

The Escazú's core objective is to impose obligations on member states to protect environmental human rights defenders and promote a comprehensive four-pillar model of environmental democracy: Access to information about the environment Public participation in environmental decision-making Access to environmental justice A healthy and sustainable environment for current and future generations The agreement is open to 33 countries in Latin America and the Caribbean. As of 2024, Of the 25 signatories, it has been ratified by sixteen: Antigua and Barbuda, Argentina, Belize, Bolivia, Chile, Dominica, Ecuador, Grenada, Guyana, Mexico, Nicaragua, Panama, Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, Saint Kitts and Nevis, Saint Lucia, and Uruguay.
CONTEXT

Despite efforts to engage Indigenous People in environmental decision-making processes, their participation often remains superficial. At the same time, environmental defenders face alarming levels of violence, making the region the most dangerous for such activities. It is estimated 200 environmental defenders (EDs) were killed globally in 2021. Latin America retained its place as the world’s deadliest region to be an ED, accounting for over three quarters of recorded fatal attacks, as half of total killings took place in just three countries last year (Mexico, Colombia and Brazil) (Source: LAB, 2022). In essence, the Escazú Agreement serves as a powerful tool for advancing environmental sustainability, social equity, and human rights in the region, offering hope for a more inclusive and sustainable future for all, particularly Indigenous communities and women (Source: CEPAL).
At the heart of the Escazú Agreement is a legally binding commitment to recognizing the crucial role of environmental defenders and ensuring their safety and empowerment.

content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2: Participatory processes and free prior informed consent

content.text: The global landscape features numerous national commissions and task forces on just transition, indicating a growing acknowledgment of the pivotal role of broad-based stakeholder participation in forging consensus toward a sustainable future. Social dialogue, involving negotiation, consultation, and information exchange among governments, workers, and unions, serves as the cornerstone of this process. These inclusive approaches are instrumental in implementing ambitious climate action, as evidenced by initiatives linked to the Paris Agreement, where considerations such as gender and youth involvement have been integrated into national climate plans. In this context, Free, Prior and Informed Consent (FPIC) established by the United Nations Declaration on the Rights of Indigenous Peoples (UNDRIP) is a crucial concept for energy transition that ensures Indigenous Peoples have the right to make decisions about projects and activities that may affect their lands and territories. “Consent” is the collective decision made by right holders, which is reached through customary decision-making processes.

In countries like South Africa, entities such as the National Economic Development and Labour Council (NEDLAC) have been established to facilitate dialogue between government, worker, employer organizations, and civil society, illustrating the potential for collaborative decision-making. Long-term decarbonization strategies require widespread understanding and acceptance among various stakeholders, underlining the significance of engaging with a diverse range of actors, including governments, indigenous groups, businesses, experts, and households. However, public opposition to renewable energy projects often stems from a real or perceived lack of inclusion in planning and decision-making processes, leading to a deficit of trust and transparency. Traditionally, energy policy evaluation has centered on cost, environmental impact, and security of supply, sidelining the societal dimension. To bridge this gap, there is a growing interest in participatory and transdisciplinary approaches to energy system modeling and planning. A conceptual framing aims to democratize decision-making processes in energy projects by emphasizing meaningful integration of social acceptance into analysis.

This meaningful integration entails several key principles, including prioritizing stakeholder input before quantitative analysis, ensuring an iterative process allowing stakeholders to shape the analysis and evaluate results, and adopting co-production and collaborative approaches involving both academic and non-academic partners throughout the research process. Engagement can manifest at various levels, from informing stakeholders through one-way communication to actively collaborating with them in shaping research questions and direction. By embracing participatory processes and ensuring prior informed consent, energy transition initiatives can bolster transparency, foster trust, and cultivate inclusive decision-making, ultimately enhancing the success and sustainability of renewable energy projects.

content.intro: M3: Just Energy Transition | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 2 | Case Study
content.title: Case Study: Colombia

content.text: Case Study RBLAC: Pacto Intercultural por La Yanama para el Desarrollo Humano y Buen Vivir en La Guajira

Access to information within the Wayúu context is fraught with complexities stemming from historical injustices, economic disparities, and cultural differences. The Wayúu people, Colombia's largest indigenous group, inhabit the Guajira region, which is targeted for the implementation of wind farms as part of Colombia's green transition plan. Despite their ancestral rights to the land, the Wayúu face marginalization and exclusion from basic infrastructure, including electricity and healthcare, due to poverty and historical neglect. The proposed wind farms not only threaten their land but also carry environmental risks, including deforestation and disruption of cultural practices such as dreaming.

Prior Informed Consent is crucial in such contexts but is often undermined by inadequate consultation processes that fail to meet international standards. Consultations are frequently initiated after project designs are already underway, limiting meaningful engagement and understanding of the implications among indigenous communities. Moreover, consultations lack cultural sensitivity and gender inclusivity, with women often excluded from decision-making processes. The involvement of companies in financing consultation processes raises concerns about the fairness and independence of these procedures. Additionally, the limited availability of information in languages like Wayuunaiki further impedes meaningful participation and informed decision-making.

“La Yanama Intercultural para el Desarrollo Humano Sostenible y el Buen Vivir en La Guajira”, established in 2020 under the leadership of Wayúu organizations, UNDP and Universidad del Rosario, fosters intercultural dialogue and collaboration. It operates through two main axes: a “school of own thought” to discuss key territorial issues from indigenous knowledge and the law of origins, and the "Pacto por La Yanama" platform. This platform serves as a space for intercultural dialogue and relationship-building among the public sector, Wayúu indigenous communities, civil society, and the private sector. One of the activities, the "Foro por la Yanama" brought together 250 people to explore national and international perspectives on how different regions can adopt models for a just energy transition, ensuring development benefits the entire population while respecting and preserving local ancestral cultures. These two axes contribute to strengthening Wayúu's right to Prior Informed (FPIC).

First, the intercultural dialogue enhances access to comprehensive information, favor experiences-sharing within Wayúu tribes (E’irruku) and supports partnerships building, thereby increasing their knowledge and bargaining power. Secondly, the platform facilitates dialogue among various stakeholders, fostering the co-creation of consensual solutions. The “Pacto por la Yanama” promotes genuine dialogue, aiming to identify solutions harmonizing with culture and nature. The space seeks to enhance understanding of the Wayúu people, their culture, intimate ancestral ties with the territory, and the public and private actors in the region to foster respectful and systemic intercultural relationships. The inclusion of tools like the U-theory developed at MIT supports this dialogue. U-theory is a practical method focusing on leadership and systems change, building collective awareness, and advocating for societal evolution, emphasizing mindfulness and awareness in redesigning collective systems.

Since 2021, the UNDP, Wayúu representatives and Universidad del Rosario, have compiled the successes, shortcomings, and learnings from the intercultural dialogue process. This analysis highlights the importance of intercultural dialogue aimed at building horizontal conditions for conversation. It also emphasizes the need for all actors to understand the dimensions of indigenous peoples' right to autonomy and self-governance. There is no one-size-fits-all formula applicable to any context. Still, this experience provides insights into a set of dialogue tools and the creation of a safe space to generate agreements. Recommendations from the “Pacto por La Yanama” emphasize the importance of sovereignty, solidarity and inclusive internal organization for the Wayúu, active listening and engagement and flexibility from government entities, and social innovation and collaboration from the private sector.

content.title: KEY TAKEAWAYS
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

takeaways.title: Human Rights Must Be Central to Sustainable Energy Transitions
takeaways.description: Renewable energy projects often involve human rights challenges like land displacement and labor violations. Ethical practices, including respecting indigenous rights and ensuring equitable benefits, must be integrated into all stages of energy transitions. Proactive measures like Free, Prior, and Informed Consent (FPIC) are essential to avoid replicating fossil fuel injustices and to promote equity.

takeaways.title: Participatory Processes are Essential for Just Transitions
takeaways.description: Inclusive stakeholder engagement, especially with indigenous and marginalized communities, is critical for successful energy transitions. Tools like FPIC and platforms such as Colombia’s Pacto Intercultural por La Yanama demonstrate how dialogue and collaboration can build trust and align projects with local values. Without meaningful participation, renewable energy initiatives risk community resistance and diminished long-term viability.

takeaways.title: Global Collaboration and Legal Frameworks Ensure Ethical Resource Management
takeaways.description: International agreements like the Escazú Agreement emphasize global cooperation to protect environmental defenders and ensure equitable access to information and justice. These frameworks provide standards for ethical resource management, balancing climate goals with human rights and social equity in renewable energy transitions.
